And as NPR's David Schaper reports, Chicago is getting closer to ushering in smart surveillance cameras.
They're supposed to warn authorities of suspicious activity.
I'm standing beneath one of those cameras on Kimball Avenue on Chicago's northwest side.
And this camera is strategically located between Roosevelt High School on one side of the street and a CTA train station on the other side of the street.

Now, the camera has a wireless antenna attached to transmit video images from this spot to the nearest police station and to the city's emergency management communications center downtown, where it's likely someone is watching me right now.
But the fact that someone is assigned to watch all of these video feeds is one of the system's limitations.
First of all, the monotony of sitting in front of a screen and focusing your attention.
IBM's Roger Rehayem is working with the city of Chicago to improve its video surveillance system.

They have done studies and shown that even the most attentive people cannot remain focused enough to the point where after a certain amount of time an event could go right before you and you can miss it.
Rehayem says that's where the use of intelligent cameras comes in.

For example, if you have a camera viewing a street corner that's sensitive and you want to know if someone's loitering on that street corner or abandons a package on that street corner, the camera can alert the authorities of that event.
Rehayem says cameras can be programmed to alert authorities to just about any activity deemed suspicious.

Such as a person or vehicle entering an area that is supposed to be off limits, a truck circling the Sears Tower too many times, a boat on the Chicago River that goes under a bridge but doesn't emerge on the other side.
Rehayem says smart cameras using analytic software can identify vehicles of certain colors, models and makes.
And he says if positioned right the cameras can read license plates or even recognize faces.
Analytics could actually start building a story for you and start building trends for you so that you can say there are patterns around the city that are of concern.
Jonathan Schachter, a public policy lecturer at Northwestern University, says there's little evidence thus far showing that security cameras really prevent crime or terrorist acts.
But he says that doesn't mean police departments shouldn't use the technology if they can.
If we have technology that can help us identify abandoned objects or suspicious behavior, I think that's terrific.
The problem is cameras both in the anti-crime and the anti-terrorism role tend to be oversold in terms of their capability.
David Schaper, NPR News, Chicago.

Dissidents in the ruling Fatah movement have broken away to form a new party to contest next month's parliamentary elections in the West Bank and Gaza.

It's led by Marwan Barghouti.

NPR's Linda Gradstein reports.
Nasser Juma, a tall, soft-spoken man with a shaven head, was on Israel's wanted list for years.
He spent most of his time on the run, rarely sleeping in the same place twice.
Many of his colleagues in the al-Aqsa Brigades have been killed or arrested.
Juma says they missed him several times, but he says the situation has eased since an Israeli-Palestinian truce was announced last February.

Now in a small hideout tucked into a corner of the casbah, or old city, of Nablus, Juma says both he and the situation have changed, and he hopes to exchange his AK-47 rifle for a seat on the Palestinian parliament.
Although he received the top spot on the Fatah list in Nablus in recent primary elections, Juma has left Fatah and joined the political movement of his mentor, Marwan Barghouti.
